image.altText: An Indigenous woman with long hair, looking sombre.

items.synopsis: Indigenous supporters of the Voice to Parliament have expressed dismay at WA Liberal leader Libby Mettam's change of heart.

title.children: 'We are so despised': Why a potential Voice defeat makes this woman 'feel like leaving the country'

image.altText: Half underwater half sunset

items.synopsis: Climate scientists say natural "anaesthetics" have been masking the true impact of climate change for years but have now worn off. Here's why the world's ocean temperatures are at record highs and what they could bring.

title.children: With the world's oceans in the middle of an unprecedented heatwave, scientists are worried

image.altText: Students, vehicles drive by shops

items.synopsis: Albany's mayor says his council has been telling a smoke and vape shop for months it isn't allowed to set up in a major shopping centre. But it put up new signs last week anyway.

title.children: Vape shop 'defies all logic' in shopping centre showdown with mayor

image.altText: A man sitting on a bench looks ahead at the sunset with a neutral expression. He's wearing an Australian Rules jersey.

items.synopsis: No professional male AFL player, past or present, has ever publicly come out as gay or bisexual. Insiders say a culture of homophobia lingers.

title.children: None of the AFL's gay male players are publicly out. Does the code's culture need to change?

image.altText: A man in a dark shirt in an office

items.synopsis: A former executive at one of the country's most disastrous share market floats in years says he wasn't surprised when the share price crashed, wiping billions of dollars from the fortunes of investors, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'Stuck with the rancid bacon': Insider lifts lid on the share market disaster that cost investors billions

image.altText: a small town surrounded by red dirt, and the green footy oval in foreground

items.synopsis: A shire president says a feud between East Kimberley families erupted into violence when their respective towns met in an outback footy grand final.

title.children: Outrage after police injured in outback footy grand final brawl

image.altText: Olga Carmona smiles with her World Cup winner's medal around her neck

items.synopsis: Just hours after a player-of-the-match performance in the Women's World Cup final, Spain captain Olga Carmona found out her father had died.

title.children: It should have been the happiest day of her life, but joy turns to sorrow for Spain's World Cup hero

image.altText: A photo of a car and a trailer attached to it which has completely collapsed

items.synopsis: A Victorian man recalls the terrifying moment his camper trailer was stolen while he and his partner were sleeping inside on the Great Ocean Road at the weekend.

title.children: Couple have four-wheel drive and camper trailer stolen while sleeping inside

image.altText: An AFP sign above a front door

items.synopsis: The court was asked to adjourn the case of a man facing 1,623 child sex abuse charges until next year due to the "voluminous" nature of the material.

title.children: 'Need more time': Court denies 2024 adjournment request for man facing more than 1,600 child sex offences

image.altText: Three men in suits outside Queensland's parliament house.

items.synopsis: Young offenders will be forcibly relocated to outback detention camps for "intensive rehabilitation" under a proposal by Katter's Australia Party.

title.children: Young offenders to be forcibly put in outback camps under Katter party proposal

image.altText: A person wearing a rain poncho walks past things covered in tarpaulin

items.synopsis: Tropical storm Hilary has inundated streets across Mexico's Baja California peninsula with deadly floodwaters, before moving over southern California, where it has swamped roads and downed trees.

title.children: Tropical storm Hilary lashes Mexico and United States

image.altText: An office building with the AGL logo showing, with a backdrop of other sky-high office buildings on a grey day.

items.synopsis: Westpac and BlueScope post their earnings at the start of another reporting-season week, AGL is set to keep Loy Yang open until mid-2035, and Qantas is hit with a class action. Follow live.

title.children: AGL to keep Loy Yang power station operational until 2035, Qantas hit with class action, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In its earnings posted today, Insurance Australia Group (IAG) also shared that it's managing $7 billion in legal claims, mostly coming from policies written by a former commercial partner that were issued to the now-defunct Greensill Capital. IAG disclosed the amount in a footnote, noting that 20 separate claims have commenced since February 2023, connected to "trade credit insurance policies" issued by Bond and Credit Co (BCC) on behalf of Insurance Australia Limited (IAL) to Greensill Capital and Greensill Bank. IAG owned a 50% share of BCC until early 2019. In the footnote, IAG denied it was liable "in respect of the claims made against it under the purported Greensill policies". "A number a number of those claims are now the subject of complex litigation proceedings currently before the Federal Court of Australia and IAL is defending all of those proceedings ," the footnote read. "IAG expects that these matters will not be resolved for a significant period of time and it is currently not known what the outcome of the proceedings or the actual value of any potential exposure to IAL will be if any claims are successful. "IAG does not consider that the face value of the claimed amounts in the proceedings provide a meaningful indication of any potential exposure of IAL. "If aggregated, these would amount to approximately $7 billion plus interest (applying exchange rates as at 31 July 2023)." IAG also noted that some of the claims are unrelated to Greensill, which became insolvent in March 2021. The insurer also notes it has " no net insurance exposure to trade credit policies sold through BCC" due to protections its put in place.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IAG notes $7b in legal claims related to collapse of Greensill Capital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I hope you're ready for another bumper earnings week — we've already had a few heavy hitters report, and it's only Monday! Here's a *very* small selection of who else we can expect to drop their earnings throughout this week, in case you want to update your calendar: Tuesday, August 22: BHP Coles Kogan.com Woodside Energy Wednesday, August 23: Domino's Pizza Estia Health Iluka Resources Santos Woolworths Thursday, August 24: Air New Zealand Medibank Private Qantas Star Entertainment Group Whitehaven Coal Friday, August 25: Ardent Leisure Costa Group Michael Hill Wesfarmers If you want to plan even further ahead (in which case, let me say I like the cut of your jib and you're in good company) here's a table I prepared earlier. Search and sort to your heart's content! (I should mention, fear not if you don't know how you'll keep up with it all this week — we'll be bringing you the latest from earnings season as it happens every day in the blog.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's which companies are reporting their earnings this week

children.content: I hope you're ready for another bumper earnings week — we've already had a few heavy hitters report, and it's only Monday!
Here's a *very* small selection of who else we can expect to drop their earnings throughout this week, in case you want to update your calendar:
If you want to plan even further ahead (in which case, let me say I like the cut of your jib and you're in good company) here's a table I prepared earlier. Search and sort to your heart's content!
(I should mention, fear not if you don't know how you'll keep up with it all this week — we'll be bringing you the latest from earnings season as it happens every day in the blog.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're still a little while away from market close, but Iress is going to be hard to pass as the worst performer on the stock market today. As of 3:15pm AEST, its stocks were down 33% — more than double the next worst performer, the A2 Milk Company. So what's the reason for its big fall today? It's all thanks to the tech company missing its earnings estimates. Iress posted a half-year net loss of $139.8 million, while its underlying net profit after tax was down almost a third to $24.4 million. And the company isn't expecting big changes in their second-half either, saying it expects "softening revenue growth and cost pressures" and has lowered its expectations accordingly. The company says the reason for its losses comes back to cost pressures, namely: increases in tech infrastructure, market data, and inflationary salary costs. Iress has also suspended its interim dividend. As for how bad their share price has been affected by the news? At one point, it fell to a 10-year low of $6.60 a share before picking back up in the middle of the day, but is now trading around the $6.70 mark .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iress is the biggest loser on the ASX today — here's why

image.altText: A woman points to pictures of honey on an electronic screen on a wall.

items.synopsis: Dusty, fruity, floral and woody are just some of the words honey sommelier Jessica Locarnini uses to describe Australia's vast range of honey flavours. She's on a mission to teach people across the country about the unique characteristics of honey.

title.children: Australia's only honey sommelier is teaching others how to appreciate local flavours one jar at a time

image.altText: A team of soccer players wearing red and blue celebrates after winning a competition

items.synopsis: While they made history on Sunday night, Spain's first Women's World Cup title will always be haunted by the players who weren't there.

title.children: Spain's World Cup win lays bare the progress and problems of women's football

image.altText: Tameka Yallop (blurry in the foreground) carries her daughter as she waves to an applauding crowd at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: It's normal to feel some symptoms of football withdrawal after the Matildas' run and the joy of the Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. So, here's how to keep riding that train.

title.children: How to keep getting your Matildas fix after the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A fire burns over a hill. It is night,  and the sky is black with the fire and smoke red and orange.

items.synopsis: A parks and wildlife director says a planned fire that got through containment lines to encroach on Alice Springs was fuelled by an introduced species of grass that is in the region "to stay".

title.children: 'Not ideal' as nearly half of outback national park goes up in flames

image.altText: Damien Hardwick stands holding a footy while wearing a Gold Coast Suns polo

items.synopsis: Damien Hardwick signs a six-year deal to coach the Gold Coast Suns months after stepping away from Richmond, where he led the Tigers to three premierships.

title.children: Suns complete Hardwick coup as triple-premiership coach joins Gold Coast

image.altText: Damaged theatre

items.synopsis: New pictures have emerged revealing the devastation caused by a Russian missile strike on the historic Ukrainian city of Chernihiv.

title.children: Pictures show aftermath of Russian missile strike on historic Ukrainian city

image.altText: Photo illustration of tree-lined Waterloo South street ahead of a state government development, housing tower in the background

items.synopsis: The redevelopment plans in Sydney's Waterloo Estate will now see nearly 500 extra social and affordable homes to address a "huge backlog".

title.children: Controversial redevelopment to unlock hundreds of social and affordable homes near Sydney CBD

image.altText: A woman in green and gold football gear shouts instructions to her teammates.

items.synopsis: Wallaroo players including Sera Naiqama, Grace Hamilton, Layne Morgan and Arabella McKenzie post a statement to social media slamming Rugby Australia.

title.children: 'It's your move': Wallaroos unite to demand fair treatment from Rugby Australia

image.altText: The Bluescope steelworks at Port Kembla near Wollongong

items.synopsis: The company, which reported a $1 billion after tax profit, says bringing a dormant coal-blast furnace back online won't lock the company into coal-based steelmaking.

title.children: 'No alternative' but to upgrade coal-blast furnace at Port Kembla, BlueScope Steel announces

image.altText: Smoke rises from Loy Yang Power Station, which is seen in silhouette against a yellow sunset

items.synopsis: An end date has been locked in for a power plant responsible for 30 per cent of Victoria's electricity generation but the future of a gaping hole beside it is less certain.

title.children: Mine for Australia's single biggest carbon emitter set to be 'repurposed', sparking concerns over future use

image.altText: A man standing among piles of rubbish in the bush.

items.synopsis: Piles of rubbish have been left in bushland on the NSW Central Coast after those living there were moved on.

title.children: Former homeless camp resembles 'landfill' near coast town's CBD

image.altText: Bernardo Arevalo Guatemala Election

items.synopsis: Preliminary results show Bernardo Arevalo has been elected Guatemalan president — a victory many voters hope will reverse widespread allegations of corruption and the authoritarianism of previous administrations.

title.children: Anti-corruption crusader wins Guatemala presidency by landslide

image.altText: man in yellow shirt and backpack

items.synopsis: Adil Abbas is the second food delivery worker to die in Sydney in the past month, prompting calls for reform of NSW's road rules.

title.children: 'We have to bury his dreams': Family mourn 19yo student killed while delivering food in Sydney

image.altText: Tayla Cox wears pink and holds her baby girl Murphy

items.synopsis: The bodies of Tayla Black and her daughter, Murphy Margaret were found by police in their Rockhampton home two weeks ago. Ms Black’s husband, Matthew Cox was charged with their murders.

title.children: 'A tragedy for everyone': Man accused of murdering his wife and 11-week-old baby faces court

image.altText: Kate Hore hugs Melbourne Demons teammates and shouts after winning the AFL Women's grand final.

items.synopsis: The AFL boosts player prize money in the women's competition by almost 100 per cent to be equal with the men, but the pool will be split across eight women's teams as opposed to four men's teams.

title.children: AFLW player prize money jumps to $1.1 million to match men's competition, but split over twice as many teams

image.altText: A family of four with cows behind them.

items.synopsis: With neighbouring farms folding on Queensland's Scenic Rim, Kay and Dave Tommerup had to choose between closing or saving their fifth-generation dairy by radically changing how they did business.

title.children: Since cutting ties with its processor this dairy farm now makes four times as much

image.altText: HMAS Canberra, off Tasmanian north coast as part of Exercise Ocean Explorer, March 2018.

items.synopsis: Three aircraft and helicopter carriers will sail together in a show of force coming shortly after Chinese coast guard ships used water cannons against Philippine vessels in the contested waterway, where disputes have long been regarded as a potential flashpoint.

title.children: Australia, US and Japan plan joint navy drills in disputed South China Sea

image.altText: England goalkeeper Mary Earps shouts at Spain's Jenni Hermoso after saving a penalty in the Women's World Cup final.

items.synopsis: One of England's best makes a costly blunder, Spain's captain shows off a hidden message and La Roja give the Lionesses a bit of love after the match. Here are five things you might have missed in the Women's World Cup final.

title.children: Five quick hits — Spain's classy gesture and what was scribbled on that shirt in the World Cup final
